snippet.textDisplay: Question. What about our relationships with third countries? We have trade deals with third countries due to our EU membership. Surely it is not in the EU's power to be able to continue those deals on our behalf after we officially leave the EU. Only those third countries can agree that they will deal with us on the same basis once we enter a transition period.
snippet.textOriginal: Question. What about our relationships with third countries? We have trade deals with third countries due to our EU membership. snippet.textDisplay:
Drawing a connection between Erasamus and the financial importance of overseas students is false. Erasmus supports short exchanges typically of a year or less rather than students completing a full course. Looking more broadly at the impact of overseas students, it is students from outside the EU who make a significant contribution to many institutions of higher education as their fees are uncapped while EU students currently pay the same fees as domestic students. Moreover, non-UK EU students are currently able to take Student Loans to cover their fees but there is no mechanism for recovering these loans if students are resident outside the UK after graduation so the direct impact on the UK economy is, if anything, negative.


In contrast, non-EU overseas students pay substantially higher fees and are not eligible for UK Student Loans. As indicated in the video, many universities draw a significant part of their income from these students and so, assuming that EU students were treated in the same way as non-EU, would potentially benefit from Brexit. It is fair to assume, of course, that the number of EU students studying at UK universities would fall post-Brexit but since they contribute no more than do UK students that would not necessarily be problematic if their places could be filled with students from elsewhere--as many institutions have indicated applications from outside the EU already exceed the available places.


In terms of UK students studying elsewhere in the EU under the Erasmus scheme, the video indicates that around 17,000 take this opportunity. This seems a significant figure until one notes that the UK student population is around 2.3 million meaning the Erasmus scheme benefits less than 1% of students. Furthermore, Erasmus only accounts for a little over half of UK students studying overseas, which suggests it is not an irreplaceable support to students. It should also be noted that Erasmus+ is not limited to EU members (it currently includes six non-EU nations as full participating countries) and the while Withdrawal Agreement makes no commitment to the programme beyond the end of 2020, the government has stated that it would continue membership if it was judged to be in the country's interest to do so.
snippet.textOriginal:
Drawing a connection between Erasamus and the financial importance of overseas students is false. Erasmus supports short exchanges typically of a year or less rather than students completing a full course. Looking more broadly at the impact of overseas students, it is students from outside the EU who make a significant contribution to many institutions of higher education as their fees are uncapped while EU students currently pay the same fees as domestic students. Moreover, non-UK EU students are currently able to take Student Loans to cover their fees *but* there is no mechanism for recovering these loans if students are resident outside the UK after graduation so the direct impact on the UK economy is, if anything, negative.


In contrast, non-EU overseas students pay substantially higher fees and are not eligible for UK Student Loans. As indicated in the video, many universities draw a significant part of their income from these students and so, assuming that EU students were treated in the same way as non-EU, would potentially benefit from Brexit. It is fair to assume, of course, that the number of EU students studying at UK universities would fall post-Brexit but since they contribute no more than do UK students that would not necessarily be problematic if their places could be filled with students from elsewhere--as many institutions have indicated applications from outside the EU already exceed the available places.


In terms of UK students studying elsewhere in the EU under the Erasmus scheme, the video indicates that around 17,000 take this opportunity. This seems a significant figure until one notes that the UK student population is around 2.3 million meaning the Erasmus scheme benefits less than 1% of students. Furthermore, Erasmus only accounts for a little over half of UK students studying overseas, which suggests it is not an irreplaceable support to students. It should also be noted that Erasmus+ is not limited to EU members (it currently includes six non-EU nations as full participating countries) and the while Withdrawal Agreement makes no commitment to the programme beyond the end of 2020, the government has stated that it would continue membership if it was judged to be in the country's interest to do so.

snippet.textDisplay:
Reply to Peter Zwegert
Your comments and all the others of your ilk illustrate exactly what follows here. You are arrogant, rude and offensive. This is all the fault of the EU - if they had given David Cameron a positive agreement, rather than vague promises which on previous experience the British people did not trust. By allowing Britain to opt out from the EU's founding ambition to forge an "ever closer union" of the peoples of Europe. Giving greater powers to national parliaments to block EU legislation. Making EU migrants who want to claim tax credits and child benefit live in the UK for a minimum of four years. Reducing of the "burden" of excessive regulation and extending the single market. Also free movement issues, relating to claiming benefits and job seekers allowances. The referendum most likely would have gone the other way, but no, political purity must come before practical common sense. Britain has about half the land mass of France with around the same population. The population density of the UK is 3.6 sq metres per head, Germany 4.5 sq metres per head and France a massive 8 sq metres per head. This is a small island, heavily populated and cannot support unlimited immigration and the provision of infrastructure, housing, health and financial support and benefits that go with it, had you given David Cameron some limited powers to the UK, he would have claimed some credit and you would not be in this mess.
However that is not the reason we voted to leave. We voted to leave because we have had enough of petty regulation, interference in our everyday lives, constant financial contribution to the Eu to give to other countries in the Eu who do not work so hard. Also the lack of democratic processes within the European Commission, the constant move to Federalisation, and the limitations on how we manage our country.
So far the Eu have done nothing but threaten us with mayhem, they want to punish us for daring to be different. They have not treated the UK fairly so far - so why should they change - not sure what Germany is going to do once they lose their £49 billion trade surplus with the UK - they call the UK Treasure Island as they sell so much to us and take back so little in return. The Eu has a net trade surplus over the UK of £66bn. Not sure how you are going to fill that without some effort on your part. We are the fifth biggest economy in the world and intend to stay that way By the way Boris has been nothing but polite in his dealings with our "friends" in Europe in spite of their constant tirade of threats and abuse, comments such as "Brexit is stupid" ( Guy Verhofstad in Eu Parliament), the anti British rantings of Donald Tusk, and the inept Barnier who totally failed in his job and is still there. If the Eu is so great why are they scared of little Britain going it alone.

Also free movement issues, relating to claiming benefits and job seekers allowances. One of the keys areas, that no one is addressing is the situation for UK Cross-Border workers in the EU. Much is said about EU workers in the UK. But Nothing about how UK citizens working in the EU under the cross-border worker treaty will be affected.
It would be informative if this was addressed in one of your videos.

snippet.textDisplay:
Fantastic news for UK citizens to be finally leaving the dictatorship of the EU!

Had the EU kept with the original EEC then I'm sure the UK would have stayed on as a member because of trade.

Because the EU over decades became hugely out of control and authoritarian and too protectionist, they have ruined it for themselves not the UK.

The EU want a United States of Europe there's no doubt about that. The EU give themselves a flag, an anthem, a currency, can overrule a member state law as 'community' law takes president, elect the EU President behind closed doors and now talks of an EU military. And the EU wonder why the UK left!!

Well done UK, you've protected your sovereignty and put country first before trade.
snippet.textOriginal:

The EU want a United States of Europe there's no doubt about that. The EU give themselves a flag, an anthem, a currency, can overrule a member state law as 'community' law takes president, elect the EU President behind closed doors and now talks of an EU military. And the EU wonder why the UK left!!

Well done UK, you've protected your sovereignty and put country first before trade.

snippet.textDisplay: "What will happen to non-citizen living in the UK" can be answered in it's simplest form with quoting the U.N. Human rights (which the UK has ratified since 1998), article 15 section 2, "No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his nationality nor denied the right to change his nationality.", sure it's likely that some conditions will still apply, but it is unlikely that UK would through out upstanding taxpaying individuals for not being citizens or having VISAs (as they would not need when UK is/was a member of the EU).
snippet.textOriginal: "What will happen to non-citizen living in the UK" can be answered in it's simplest form with quoting the U.N. Human rights (which the UK has ratified since 1998), article 15 section 2, "No one shall be arbitrarily deprived of his nationality nor denied the right to change his nationality.", sure it's likely that some conditions will still apply, but it is unlikely that UK would through out upstanding taxpaying individuals for not being citizens or having VISAs (as they would not need when UK is/was a member of the EU).
